title-group.article-title: Offshore Wind Resource Assessment in Rhode Island Waters

abstract.p: The validity and accuracy of the Weibull distribution to represent wind speed distributions and estimate the wind power resource is assessed for Southern New England coastal waters. Excellent agreement is found between Weibull-derived and measured mean power resource estimates, confirming the validity of the two-parameter Weibull distribution in the study area. The mean power resource and its spatial variability are assessed and mapped in terms of theoretical and technical power estimates. Finally, a sensitivity study is performed to assess the impact on power estimates at hub height of a hypothetical wind turbine, of uncertainties of three main controlling factors : (1) mean wind speed, (2) Weibull shape parameter, and (3) shear coefficient of the lower atmospheric boundary layer. Results are presented in terms of expected mean theoretical and technical power, and confidence interval, at a hypothetical 110 meters hub height, on a high resolution grid (10 arc-seconds) based on stochastic estimations.

caption.p: SAMP area (red dashed line) and extension towards Massachussets. Measurement stations are represented by triangular symbols; square symbols mark the WIS virtual station locations.

Wind data sources (data station locations are mapped in Fig. 1) and shape coefficient value estimated from Weibull distributions. WF: Weather Flow Inc.; AWS: AWS True Wind Inc.; CO: Coastal Observatory (MVCO)-WHOI; z₁ is actual measurement height or virtual station (WIS) elevation

Comparison between simulated power resource from Weibull distributions, using the Monte Carlo (MC) method (PMC), and the mean instantaneous power calculated at each station from a full time series (Pₒ).
Mean theoretical power in and around SAMP area, based on Eq. (5).
Mean usable power available at turbine hub height (zh = 110 m), assuming cut-in, cut off, and rated speeds of, uin = 3.5, uout = 27, and uR = 15 m/s, respectively.

Mean technical power available at turbine hub height (zh = 110 m), assuming cut-in, cut off, and rated speeds of, uin = 3.5, uout = 27, and uR = 15 m/s, respectively and the aerodynamic limitation due to Betz law (Eq. 3).

Power sensitivity to the shape parameter k, estimated as the ratio of the mean expected power to the mean expected power assuming a standard value k = 2. [For instance, assuming a shape factor of 2 instead of 2.1 would overestimate the expected power by about 5%].
Sources of uncertainty in mean power resource at measurement level
Sensitivity of mean expected power resource at hub height z₂ = 110 m, to shear coefficient value

Theoretical Power resource sensitivity to the shear coefficient: BISC (blue) compared to standard profile, SOSC (green), and modeled profile, MOSC. (red). The red dot represent the power calculated from Eq. 9 using AWS wind speed data and shear coefficient value, MOSC. The blue dots are estimated using Eq. 9, and wind speed distributions and parameters calculated from measured data as well as BISC shear coefficient value.
Technical Power resource sensitivity to the shear coefficient; BI profile 95% confidence interval (BISC; dash blue) compared to standard profiles, SOSC (plain blue) and MOSC (plain red) (Table 3).
Uncertainties associated with wind power parameters: definition, associated statistics and resulting combined uncertainty for 2 expected elevations, assuming Block Island wind characteristics
